awd_titl_txt: Understanding How Aluminum Moves Around a Friction Stir Welding Tool in order to Prevent Welding Defects
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support fundamental scientific research that will investigate how aluminum moves around a friction stir welding tool and how this movement influences the formation of sub-surface defects (voids). Due to its many advantages over other welding processes, friction stir welding has rapidly gained popularity in numerous manufacturing industries. However, certain limitations have slowed its mass implementation. This research seeks to address a lack of knowledge about two limitations in friction stir welding: (1) the need for costly post weld inspection of sub-surface defects in high-reliability applications (for example: defense and aerospace industries), and (2) the desire to increase processing speed to allow for high-volume production (for example: automotive industry). Faster welding speeds increase the likelihood of defect formation. A fundamental understanding of the precise mechanisms of material flow around the friction stir tool and its role in sub-surface defect formation is currently lacking. This research will generate the knowledge necessary to help U.S. manufacturers predict defect formation, hence allow them to design a friction stir welding process that produces defect-free welds. Addressing the aforementioned limitations will greatly expedite the mass implementation of this joining method, which will have a positive impact on U.S. manufacturing, the U.S. economy, and National Security. The award will also facilitate training of the future workforce as students across all levels will gain exposure to and experience in advanced joining technologies. Knowledge generated from this project will be distributed publicly through conference presentations, journal articles, industry tours, and open house engineering expositions.

The goal of this research is to generate a fundamental understanding of the physics behind the intermittent movement (an extrusion-like process) of metal around the friction stir tool once per tool revolution. This phenomenon has been widely reported in the manufacturing engineering community by means of force measurements and by studying weld cross-sections after completing the weld. However, an understanding of why this intermittent material movement occurs and direct in-process observations do not exist. One leading hypothesis is that a cavity opens up in the wake of the advancing tool and that material is subsequently extruded into this cavity during each rotation of the tool. In a good welding condition, this cavity is completely filled. However, when there is a breakdown in the material flow, the cavity is not filled completely and a defect (void) remains. This hypothesis will be tested by means of novel, in-process proton radiography of the friction stir welding process of an aluminum alloy. Proton radiography at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center provides the capability of producing a series of radiographic images (like x-rays) of the weld zone that will show whether or not a cavity is forming and filling. The knowledge gained through this physical experimentation, combined with other experiments conducted at the University of Madison-Wisconsin, will drive the numerical simulation of the intermittent flow phenomenon. Simulation of this phenomenon is largely absent from the published literature. In this work, the complex material flow and cavity formation and filing processes will be modeled and simulated using advanced Lagrangian based numerical techniques. Ultimately, this will provide the means to predict defect formation, and design measures to avoid it during production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant was focused on better understanding a solid-state metal welding process: friction stir welding. In other words, a technology by which two metal pieces can be joined together without melting. This can be described as a hot working process where the workpiece is elevated to a temperature just below the melting point to make it possible for a friction stir tool to plastically deform (move) metal around, mix it, and then let it cool back to room temperature in such a way that a strong and solid joint is formed. The motivation for studying this particular manufacturing process is the important advantages over melting-based welding processes: process efficiency, speed, less energy consumption, ability to produce fully dense welds, ductile properties of the weld joint, and that it is easier to join dissimilar metals.  

The fundamental goal was to better understand why and when the flow of aluminum around the tool breaks down and leaves behind cavities (voids) in the weld joint. To understand the formation of voids, one must observe the changes in material flow over time (dynamics), as well as with different welding parameters. These voids can significantly reduce the strength and other properties of the joint. With a better understanding of when and why cavities are formed it will be possible to predict this phenomenon. If one can predict cavity formation accurately, then controlling it is possible, as well as identifying when and where there is a greater chance of a poor-quality joint. Creating the ability to do this will reduce the need for costly post weld inspection of sub-surface defects in high-reliability applications (for example: defense and aerospace industries), and facilitate increased processing speeds needed for high-volume production (for example: automotive industry). 

The research was designed around testing the following hypothesis: "Intermittent formation and filling of a cavity, once per revolution, at the trailing edge of the friction stir tool, is an inherent part of friction stir welding and processing of aluminum alloys.? In other words, the objective is to prove that a sub-surface cavity is formed at the trailing edge of the friction stir tool and subsequently filled during every rotation of the tool, under operating conditions that result in a fully dense weld and ones that result in defects/voids (incomplete filling of said cavity). It is hypothesized that this intermittent material flow occurs for every friction stir weld. This NSF-funded team of researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, in close collaboration with scientists at Argonne National Laboratory, conducted the first high-speed high-intensity X-ray imaging of the metal flow inside a workpiece during friction stir welding of aluminum alloys. These experiments were conducted at the Advanced Photon Source, located at Argonne National Laboratory. The resulting X-ray videos (20,000 frames per second) clearly showed cavities opening up and closing three times per friction stir tool rotation, even for welds that ended up being cavity/defect/porosity free. The cavities were formed three times per revolution because the friction stir tools used in this study had three flats on the probe: the cross-section of the tool inside of the aluminum looked like a modified triangle. The edges that extended the furthest from the axis of rotation would plow material away leaving a cavity in the area behind. The next edge would push material into that cavity to fill it. However, if the tool started moving too fast then the cavity would get too big to fill in and cavity would be left behind. 

Additionally, multi-physics numerical simulations (finite element method) of the friction stir welding process were performed with the objective of predicting the cavity formation, closure, and incomplete filling. The team was able to show that these types of simulations could predict this phenomena and they qualitatively matched what was observed in the high-speed X-ray imaging. This project also supported the experimental observation and numerical prediction of the effect of a friction stir tool's runout and a machine tool's stiffness on the formation of cavities, and ultimately voids inside of the weld. Together, the findings of this research project will provide the means to predict defect formation, and design measures to avoid it during production.  

This research project partially supported the training and education of six graduate students in advanced manufacturing. All of them are gainfully in the advanced manufacturing or education sector. The results were publicly disseminated in the form of graduate theses, journal papers, conference papers, and conference presentations.


Last Modified: 09/25/2023
Modified by: Frank E Pfefferkorn

Images (1 of )
  • This image shows one frame of the high-speed X-ray video of metal moving around the friction stir tool during welding. It shows a cavity forming at trailing edge of the tool and filling. A fully dense weld is seen to the left of the tool.

    X-ray Image of Cavity Forming
  • This image shows the experimental setup used at the Advanced Photon Source to collect high-speed X-raying images of the metal flow inside the aluminum workpiece during friction stir welding
